title: Expressing Desire & Plans
description: Learn to talk about what you want to do and your plans

vocabulary.exampleSentence: にほんにいきたいです。
vocabulary.exampleMeaning: I want to go to Japan.

examples.japanese: にほんごをもっとべんきょうしたいです。
examples.reading: Nihongo wo motto benkyou shitai desu.
examples.meaning: I want to study Japanese more.

grammar.notes: たい conjugates like an い-adjective: たくない (don't want), たかった (wanted).

grammar.pattern: Verb dictionary form + つもりです

examples.japanese: らいねんにほんにいくつもりです。
examples.reading: Rainen Nihon ni iku tsumori desu.
examples.meaning: I plan to go to Japan next year.

examples.japanese: あしたはやくおきるつもりです。
examples.meaning: I intend to wake up early tomorrow.

grammar.notes: つもり shows a firm intention. For schedules/appointments, use よてい instead.

kanji.mnemonics: A person (亻) leaning against a tree (木) - resting.
A person (亻) with something (可) - asking 'what is that?'

culturalNote: In Japanese, you usually don't directly ask someone else '何がしたいですか' (what do you want to do?) as it can put pressure on them. Instead, offer options: 'コーヒーとおちゃ、どちらがいいですか' (Coffee or tea, which is good?).
practiceGoals: Talk about plans with つもり
Conjugate たい like an い-adjective
